topic.title: HP Helion 1.1 Development Platform: Kato Command Reference

body.p: Kato is the Application Lifecycle Service command line administration utility.

section.title: Command List
section.p: Config: Manipulates configuration values of Helion components.
Data: Import, export, or repair Helion system data
Debug: Commands for debugging Helion internals.
History: Display the kato commands that have been run
Info: Display information about this node or cluster, including assigned and available roles.
Inspect: Detect common problems with your installation.
License: Set the license in use for this microcloud or cluster.
Logging: Logging utilities.
Node: Node management
OP: Various operational commands
Patch: Update a cluster with post-release fixes.
Process: Start, stop, or restart individual processes. Generally not required.
Relocate: Move containers, application droplets, or services to a new mount point
Report: Generate a report that can be sent to technical support.
Restart: Restart the service or individual roles.
Role: Management of node roles
Shell: Interactive shell for kato
Start: Start the ALS or start individual roles.
Status: List configured roles and their current status across the cluster.
Stop: Stop the service or individual roles.
Version: Display the version of ALS currently in use.

section.title: Config
section.p: Manipulate configuration values of service components.
config get [options] <component> <key-path>
config set [options] <component> <key-path> <value>
config del [options] <component> <key-path>
config push [options] <component> <key-path> <value>
config pop [options] <component> <key-path> <value>

ul.li: <value>: If value is not given for set, then it is read from STDIN.
<component>: Can be cluster, local or the name of a process.

row.entry: For set, use JSON format when setting config key values. For get, use JSON format when displaying output.
Use YAML format when retrieving or setting config key values. YAML is the default output format.
Force updating value to different type

section.title: Log Drain Add
section.p: Add a new log drain.
Add a drain to receive system logs

codeblock.codeph: kato log drain add system_splunk udp://logs.splunk.com:1234/

section.p: Add a drain to forward all application and system logs as json

codeblock.codeph: kato log drain add -f json -p apptail,systail app_sys_splunk \ udp://logs.splunk.com:1235/

section.p: Add a drain with a custom or named format,

codeblock.codeph: kato log drain add -f ": " system_splunk_2 \ udp://logs.splunk.com:1236/ kato log drain add -f systail-syslog system_splunk_2 \ udp://logs.splunk.com:1236/

section.p: Pass custom parameters to a drain

codeblock.codeph: kato log drain add mydrain redis://localhost:6379 key=logdata

row.entry: Message key prefix; possible values: systail, event, apptail (comma-separated, no spaces)

section.title: Node Reset
section.p: Reset the ALS VM to its default configuration.

codeblock.codeph:
node reset factory
node reset docker
node reset services
node reset --help

ul.li: factory: returns the VM to its state prior to first boot.
docker: removes all Docker containers and deletes all but the ALS release images; not meant for general use.
services: removes all service data; not meant for general use.

section.title: Node Retire
section.p: Gracefully retires a DEA node from the cluster. New instances of the apps are started on other available DEAs before the retiring DEA is shut down.

row.entry: Retire the specified DEA node; if unspecified, the local node is used.

section.title: Node Upgrade
section.p: Upgrade the installation to the latest available version, preserving deployed applications, config, services, and other state.
Will operate on current node by default; upgrade can be done for the entire cluster at once (with --cluster) or for a specific node (with --node).

row.entry: Updates kato node upgrade to the latest codebase.
The version to upgrade to. If unspecified, the latest version is used.

Comma separated list of roles defining the order that roles should be upgraded in a cluster.
Shows the status of upgrades on a node.
Run a development upgrade (internal use only).
The IP of the node to act as a cache for all nodes in the cluster during upgrade.
Downloads the files required to perform an upgrade without starting an upgrade. When using this option, --cache-ip must be specified.
